Award.AwardTitle: Three Strategies to Improve STEM Graduation Rates

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Cal Poly University - Pomona plans to increase STEM graduation rate from 28% to 48% to match the rate for the rest of campus. The program has three components: 1) course development in three gateway courses that are prerequisites for further STEM study, 2) enhanced first year experiences including an innovative orientation course, and 3) apprenticeship opportunities for students.

Gateway courses in physics, calculus and chemistry are being revised to incorporate interactive teaching, inquiry-based learning and assignments that reveal the societal benefits of STEM fields. The revised freshman orientation course promotes community, engages students in problem-solving activities, introduces college survival skills and stimulates interest in STEM careers. Students are provided apprenticeship opportunities to build community and establish relationships with other students and faculty. Cal Poly - Pomona has a diverse student body and produces the largest number of underrepresented engineers and computer scientists in the state. Successful strategies will be replicated at other California State Universities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The CPP STEP program has implemented some planned program activities but redirected efforts during Year 4 of the program to better address CPP students’ and the institution’s needs, specifically the need to create and promote UR opportunities at CPP. Under the strong leadership of the STEP PI and staff, the program has without question expanded UR opportunities at CPP. The OUR was developed as an outgrowth of STEP and has become the centralized location for information on UR at CPP. Furthermore, Bronco Scholar, which was originally established to sustain STEP-created materials, has expanded to include student and faculty research and serves as a hub that connects UR to the scholarly community.

With respect to the original program objectives, most overall goals have been partially met. Since the grant’s initiation in 2010, the College of Science 5-year graduation rate has increased from 38.0% to 45.1% and from 22.9% to 48.9% in the College of Engineering respectively. The original objective was to increase the graduation rate of STEM students at CPP from 28.7% to 48.0% over a 5-year period. Year 6 analyses suggest that participating in research-related activities benefits some students’ academic outcomes. On average, students who participated in a research-related activity had a higher Fall 2015 cumulative GPA than those who did not participate in a research-related activity. Retention rated did not differ, however, between students who did and did not participate in research. The original objective was to increase the retention rates of participating STEM students by 50% and improve their academic achievement by an average 20% increase in GPA. In Year 6, approximately 32.4% of students in either the College of Science or Engineering participated in at least one research-related activity (an increase from a baseline of 22%). More students have a) actively sought out research opportunities (as indicated by the increase in number of students attending the OUR); b) are presenting their research at conferences (as indicated by the increase in number of student presenters at the CPP SRC); and c) uploading and downloading research projects from Bronco Scholar (as indicated by Google Analytics and the Digital Initiatives Librarian). The original objective was to increase undergraduate participation in research-related activities in the Colleges of Science and Engineering to 70%.

Finally, the last objective – to disseminate the program model to institutions of higher learning has been fully met. The STEP team disseminated best practices at four conferences in Year 6, broadening their dissemination efforts to national and international audiences.

Both the OUR and Bronco Scholar have been institutionalized and/or incorporated into other support programs on campus and thus will be sustained well beyond the duration of STEP. Best practices such as Bronco Scholar and supportive services promoted by the OUR should continue to serve as a model for other campuses as well as other Hispanic-Servicing Institutions throughout the United States.

 


Last Modified: 08/17/2016
Modified by: Winny Dong
